<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 278, 170, 293]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 298, 329, 313]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Alternative to Practical  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 278, 905, 333]]<|/det|>
0625/62 February/March 2017 1 hour  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 338, 415, 354]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 359, 368, 374]]<|/det|>
No Additional Materials are required.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 388, 407]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 719, 490]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. Write in dark blue or black pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 500, 767, 545]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions. Electronic calculators may be used. You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 555, 760, 585]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 512, 137]]<|/det|>

She moves the screen until a sharp image of the triangle is seen on the screen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 327, 672, 346]]<|/det|> The student measures the height of the illuminated triangle \(h_{\mathrm{O}}\). <|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[541, 352, 917, 377]]<|/det|> \[h_{\mathrm{O}} = \mathrm{1.5cm}\] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 388, 920, 424]]<|/det|> Measure and record, in Table 3.1, the height of the image of the triangle \(h_{\mathrm{I}}\) on the screen, as shown in Fig. 3.2. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 406, 920, 425]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[364, 432, 631, 593]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 607, 534, 626]]<|/det|> <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 670, 539, 688]]<|/det|> Table 3.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 696, 789, 861]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 863, 91]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating how the material of a spring affects its behaviour when stretched.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 539, 122]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 134, 546, 152]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 703, 168]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 532, 183]]<|/det|>
a wooden rod approximately \(1\mathrm{cm}\) in diameter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 463, 199]]<|/det|>
other standard laboratory equipment.
